security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill with minimal security risks. Code is educational, focused on p5.js generative art. No malicious patterns detected. Apache 2.0 licensed.

content.value_statement: Create original generative art using p5.js with parametric controls and seeded randomness for reproducible, explorable algorithmic compositions.
actual_capabilities: Generate original algorithmic art based on computational philosophy
Create interactive HTML artifacts with p5.js
Implement seeded randomness for reproducible outputs
Build parametric controls for real-time art exploration
Use noise functions, particle systems, and flow fields
Implement animated or static generative systems
limitations: Performance limited by browser p5.js capabilities
Canvas size constrained by browser memory (typically max 2000x2000)
No backend persistence (artwork exists in browser only)
Single-file HTML output means all code must be embedded
Real-time parameter adjustment works better for < 20k particles
Cannot create photo-realistic or text-based art directly

best_practices: Start with a clear algorithmic philosophy (4-6 paragraphs) describing the computational approach before coding
Use seeded randomness (randomSeed/noiseSeed) for reproducible, explorable variations
Design 3-5 key parameters that meaningfully affect the visual output without overwhelming users
Organize parameters into logical UI sections (Seed, Parameters, Colors, Actions)
Test performance with intended particle counts - optimize if frame rate drops below 30fps
Include interactive seed navigation (prev/next/random) to encourage exploration
Keep parameter ranges narrow enough to produce valid art (avoid extreme values)
Use Anthropic branding consistently (Poppins font, light colors, gradient backdrop)
Document the algorithmic philosophy in markdown alongside the interactive artifact
Ensure the artifact works immediately in browser - no setup or external dependencies needed
anti_patterns: Creating static images with randomness sprinkled on top - focus on algorithmic process
Copying established artists' work instead of creating original algorithmic visions
Over-parameterization - 15+ sliders overwhelms users; 3-5 key parameters are ideal
Unclear or poetic algorithmic descriptions - be specific about computational approach
Performance degradation - test with max parameter values to ensure smooth execution
Ignoring seed reproducibility - same seed should always produce identical output
Dark themes or non-Anthropic branding in UI - maintain consistent design system
Creating separate .js files instead of self-contained HTML - embedding keeps artifacts portable
Emphasizing static composition over algorithmic emergence - beauty should come from process
Parameters that don't meaningfully affect output - every slider should visibly change the result

faq.question: What's the difference between algorithmic art and using filters on photos?
faq.answer: Algorithmic art generates visual compositions entirely through code - mathematical relationships, noise functions, and particle behaviors. The beauty emerges from the computational process itself. Each run with a different seed produces a completely new, unique artwork. This is generative art, not image manipulation.

faq.question: Do I need to know advanced mathematics?
faq.answer: You don't need graduate-level math, but comfort with basic concepts helps: vectors, noise functions (Perlin noise), trigonometry for angles/directions, and simple physics (force, velocity, acceleration). The skill guides you through the algorithmic philosophy first - the implementation follows from that vision.

faq.question: Can I use this for commercial art projects?
faq.answer: Yes. The Apache 2.0 license permits commercial use. You own the algorithmic philosophy and implementation. Just respect copyright if you reference other artists' work - embed references as algorithmic DNA, not literal copies.

faq.question: How many particles can I realistically handle?
faq.answer: Modern browsers typically handle 10k-50k particles smoothly at 60fps depending on update complexity. Simple motion (following a field) handles larger counts. Complex inter-particle interactions (collision detection) require fewer. Test and optimize based on your specific algorithm.

faq.question: What if I want static (non-animated) art?
faq.answer: Call noLoop() in setup() to generate once. The algorithm runs during setup, then draws the static result. Users can still explore variations by changing the seed.

faq.question: How do I embed artistic concepts into the algorithm?
faq.answer: The algorithmic philosophy describes your concept in computational terms. For example, 'neural networks' becomes: nodes as particles, connections as vectors, signal strength as color/opacity. The concept lives in the algorithm's behavior, not in the final image.

faq.question: Can I use this skill to copy existing generative art?
faq.answer: No - this skill emphasizes creating original algorithmic visions. Copying other artists' algorithms violates their intellectual property. Instead, develop your own computational philosophy and unique approach.

faq.question: What if the artifact runs slowly?
faq.answer: Reduce particle count, simplify force calculations, or use spatial hashing for collision detection. Profile your code to find bottlenecks. Sometimes simpler algorithms can be more visually interesting than complex ones.

faq.question: How do I make the art reproducible with seeds?
faq.answer: Always call randomSeed(params.seed) and noiseSeed(params.seed) before generating. Then all random() and noise() calls will be deterministic. Same seed = identical output every time.

faq.question: Can I share the HTML artifact without coding?
faq.answer: The skill creates a self-contained HTML file you can save and email. Anyone with a browser can open it and explore - no installation needed. They can adjust parameters, navigate seeds, and export images.
